properties.Name: StoreDisplayArea

Columns.Name: StoreId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Store.

Columns.Name: AreaId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Area.

Columns.Name: AreaPeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the store store display area is available for merchandising.

Columns.Name: AreaPeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date until which the store store display area is available for merchandising.

Columns.Name: FloorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Floor.

Columns.Name: FloorPeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the store floor is available for merchandising.

Columns.Name: LocationAddress
Columns.Description: A unique address within a Warehouse that may identify a Building, Storeroom, Area, Aisle, Shelf, Tier, Bin etc.

Columns.Name: FloorLocationXCoordinate
Columns.Description: The floor location x-coordinate of the Store Display Area center point.

Columns.Name: FloorLocationYCoordinate
Columns.Description: The floor location y-coordinate of the Store Display Area center point.

Columns.Name: AreaRotationX
Columns.Description:
Rotation X is the amount of rotation (in degrees) relative to the X axis of the Store Floor.  The rotation point is the center of the object which is aligned with the Floor Location X,Y coordinate.

Rotation angle is usually defined according to the right-hand rule. Namely, the angle is a positive value when the rotation appears clockwise when looking in the positive direction of the axis, and negative values when the rotation appears counter-clockwise.

Columns.Name: AreaRotationY
Columns.Description:
Rotation Y is the amount of rotation (in degrees) relative to the Y axis of the object.  The Y axis refers to vertical position (perpendicular to the base).  A positive rotation would mean that the front of the object's base plane is higher than the back, whereas a negative value indicates the front of the object's base plane is lower than the back.  

Since the Store Display Area is essentially an imaginary outline directly on the floor, it's base plane would always match the base plane of the floor, so the Rotation Y would be 0.

Columns.Name: AreaRotationZ
Columns.Description:
Rotation Z is the amount of rotation (in degrees) relative to the Z axis of the object.  The Z axis refers to the rotational axis or rotational centerline of the object.  A positive rotation would mean that one side of the object's base plane is higher than the other,  whereas a negative value indicates the opposite side is higher.  In other words, it is leaning to the left or to the right.

 Since the Store Display Area is essentially an imaginary outline directly on the floor, it's base plane would always match the base plane of the floor, so the Rotation Z would be 0.

Columns.Name: AreaLength
Columns.Description: The length of the Store Display Area measured in the unit of measure specified by the Dimensions Unit of Measure ID.

Columns.Name: AreaWidth
Columns.Description: The width of the Store Display Area measured in the unit of measure specified by the Dimensions Unit of Measure ID.

Columns.Name: DimensionsUnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: AreaTotalFloorSpace
Columns.Description: The total floor space of the area measured in the unit of measure specified by the Area Unit of Measure ID.  The area may have an irregular shape so may not necessarily be the product of the designated Length times width.

Columns.Name: AreaUnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Properties.Description:
Areas are sections of a site. Like sites, areas can be organized by various means, including physical layout or business function. Under S88, not every section of a plant need be part of an area, especially if that section has nothing to do with batch control.

While S88 defines all seven levels and considers each important, it's the bottom four levels that really matter. Those four are shown in Figure 10 by a slightly darker color. The reason for this extra importance is that batches are typically made and contained within the level called process cell, and the remaining three levels are all subsequent components of a process cell.

properties.Description:
Areas are sections of a site. Like sites, areas can be organized by various means, including physical layout or business function. Under S88, not every section of a plant need be part of an area, especially if that section has nothing to do with batch control.

While S88 defines all seven levels and considers each important, it's the bottom four levels that really matter. Those four are shown in Figure 10 by a slightly darker color. The reason for this extra importance is that batches are typically made and contained within the level called process cell, and the remaining three levels are all subsequent components of a process cell.
